We're hitting this error too. It looks to me like the problem is from the migration named `b4456560d4f3_change_table_unique_constraint.py`:

```
def upgrade():
    try:
        # Trying since sqlite doesn't like constraints
        op.drop_constraint(
            u'tables_table_name_key', 'tables', type_='unique')
        op.create_unique_constraint(
            u'_customer_location_uc', 'tables',
            ['database_id', 'schema', 'table_name'])
    except Exception:
        pass
```

This tries to drop the old constraint on just `table_name`, but fails on sqlite which doesn't know how to drop constraints. (You need to [create a new table, copy everything over, drop the old table, then rename the new table to the old name](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1884787/how-do-i-drop-a-constraint-from-a-sqlite-3-6-21-table).) So you are left with the old constraint, and never add the new improved one.

This code also shows why the problem doesn't happen in Postgres: there the migration succeeds, so the old too-restrictive constraint is dropped.

Hi @graceguo-supercat Unfortunately I can't get SuperSet to build locally right now so I can't test, but...

The dialog presented to the user gives them the option to save / overwrite slices as well as save / overwrite dashboards.

So, the above check that gives the user an error when saving / overwriting the slice will need to be two-fold:

```python
if action == 'overwrite' and not slice_overwrite_perm:
  return json_error_response("You don't have the rights to alter this slice", status=400)

if action == 'saveas' and not slice_add_perm:
  return json_error_response("You don't have the rights to create a slice", status=400)
```

If the user has those permissions, a dashboard permission check would be needed before the section saving / creating dashboards:

```python
dash = ... # find dashboard from request
check_ownership(dash, raise_if_false=True)
... # update dashboard
```

```python
dash_add_perm = self.can_access('can_add', 'DashboardModelView')
if request.args.get('add_to_dash') == 'new' and not dash_add_perm:
  return json_error_response("You don't have the rights to create a dashboard", status=400)

# ... save dashboard
```

That is mostly psuedo-code since I can't actually test it right now and I'm not sure the best design for error handling here.

Also, from a UX viewpoint, it would be nice to have the "Save" button in the explore view be disabled if the user doesn't have the ability to save / alter slices, but I have no idea what those changes would look like.

As a bit of an expansion on this, I found that upgrading my thirft-sasl was the fix:

`pip install thrift-sasl --upgrade`
Have you solved this problem?

@mistercrunch We are running into a similar issue -- we are in an enterprise environment and management uses Internet Explorer by default.

This feature isn't related to the contents of the Markup slice -- it has to do with the implementation.

When the markup slice changed to use an iframe, the contents of the iframe are now populated using the `srcdoc` attribute: https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/144f516700b7c6d0d4a0db3d4f53e077f6109cc8/superset/assets/visualizations/markup.js#L28

Unfortunately, `srcdoc` is not support in the latest IE: https://www.w3schools.com/TAgs/att_iframe_srcdoc.asp

Is it possible to replace the contents of the iframe using jQuery instead of embedding it in the `srcdoc` attribute? Something similar to the following? https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13214419/alternatives-to-iframe-srcdoc

@mistercrunch Are you sure that this fixes #3660? I included your changes in our installation and restarted superset, and these log messages still are flooding the console log. I don't assume that I was supposed to build anything here, as this is only a py file, right?
@rumbin you have default log level set to debug, you have to raise it to something less spammy.

Cannot reproduce this in 0.20.4 and PostgreSQL as database. The columns in the CSV are even more precisely labeled, as you can see in the following comparison:

superset 0.20.4:
```
a,a__1
a,a
```

superset 0.15.4:
```
a,a
a,a
```

@austenhead Can you confirm, and close the issue?

Well this is embarassing.
I didn't notice that the _default_ LOG_LEVEL is set to DEBUG.

Thanks anyway, @xrmx...
Can anyone provide me with an explanation as to what does rolling option do in the advanced analytical part of a time series-line chart?

Forgot to mention: we are using a Redis cache.

My guts feeling is that in SQLLab the  pandas dtypes aren't set correctly when fetching the data from the cache.
How is this done differently in Explore?
This PR restore some translation but this issue is because language does not change when you change it with the tiny flag
@mistercrunch  - sorry for the late response. I restarted the web server and everything is working fine now. thank you for your response
Looks to me as if #2036 is the culprit for the regression compared to 0.15.4. (Although I really appreciate the speedup of using the cache for the CSV download.)

This ticket is first on google for "superset mssql" and I decided to add short instructions here: First of all you have to install superset as described in manual and after that (inside venv) do next steps:
pip uninstall pymssql
sudo apt-get install libssl-dev
wget ftp://ftp.freetds.org/pub/freetds/stable/freetds-0.95.tar.gz
tar -xvzf freetds-0.95.tar.gz
cd freetds-0.95
./configure --with-openssl=/usr/include/openssl --with-tdsver=7.3
make
sudo make install
pip install --no-binary pymssql pymssql
sudo ln -s /usr/local/lib/libsybdb.so.5 /usr/lib/libsybdb.so.5
sudo ldconfig

Now you have to create mssql connection URL: it should look like that:
mssql+pymssql://USER%40SERVER:PASSWORD@SERVER.database.windows.net:1433/DATABASE
I revert to 0.18.5, the problem solved. I guess there's some bug in the latest version ?

Here is what I did on the new server -

# Install superset
pip install superset

# Create an admin user (you will be prompted to set username, first and last name before setting a password)
fabmanager create-admin --app superset

# Initialize the database
superset db upgrade

# Load some data to play with
superset load_examples

# Create default roles and permissions
superset init
